key_points: A winter freeze in Texas caused widespread power outages, contributing to hundreds of deaths and leaving millions without power.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's preliminary report attributes the outages mainly to freezing or insufficient winterizing of generators.
44% of outage issues were due to freezing, while 31% were because of natural gas fuel shortages.
Most natural gas production and processing facilities were not protected from load shedding, leading to a decline in supply.
The federal agency has offered 28 recommendations, focusing on winterizing equipment and conducting annual winterization training.
A similar report was issued in 2011, but most recommendations were not implemented by power providers.
Experts emphasize the importance of adhering to the new recommendations to avoid repeat occurrences.
The Texas power grid's improvement requires making economic incentives for energy producers to enhance reliability.
ERCOT is working with the PUC to implement legislated mandates and improve grid reliability, in response to the report's findings.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's full report and recommendations are available on their website.
spokespersons: Daniel Cohan (Associate Professor of Environmental Engineering, Rice University)
Ramanan Krishnamoorti (Chief Energy Officer, University of Houston)
